item.title: How to build a chrome extension to automate stuff
item.description: Recently I was looking for a way to send bulk text messages via Google Voice. I’m not talking about MMS messages - those are terrible for large groups, and have reliability issues with fringe carriers and MVNOs. I couldn’t find any way to do that, and I decided to write a chrome extension to automate it myself. I learned a few helpful things along the way, and thought I’d share them here.

item.description: If you want to use a Gmail account as a free SMTP server on your Ubuntu-Linux server, you will find this article useful. This guide is tested with Ubuntu 12.04. item.title: The one book that every software developer should read
item.description: There are many books recommended for software developers. There’s an entire Stack Overflow thread dedicated to this topic and many blog posts as well. I’ve recently read Designing Data Intensive Applications, The Design of Everyday Things, and Don’t Make Me Think by Steve Krug. I learned many useful, applicable things from each of those. However, there is one book above all others that I feel that all developers should read. It isn’t about building software, it’s about building relationships.

item.title: How to install Steam on a Chromebook
item.description: There are already numerous guides out there for installing Steam on Chromebooks with Crouton, but that requires putting your Chromebook into developer mode, which is not ideal. However, in 2018 Google added native Linux app support to Chrome OS via project Crostini. This is a guide for installing Steam on a Chromebook via the native Linux app support. Step 1: Check if your device is supported First, make sure that your device supports Linux apps.

item.title: How to use Chrome OS’s native Samba client
item.description: As reported a few months ago, the engineers at Google have been working on adding native Samba support to the Chrome OS Files app. This is a guide for using this new feature, along with caveats. Step 1: Enable the feature This feature is still in the experimental phase as of Chrome OS 68, so you’ll need to enable it. Navigate to chrome://flags/#native-smb in your browser and change the dropdown for “Native Smb Client” to “Enabled”.

item.title: How to send bulk texts with Google voice
item.description: Sometimes you want to send a text message to a large group of people. MMS isn’t a great approach — you’d be starting a group chat with a bunch of people that may not even have each other’s contact info. Some people may be annoyed if you do that, especially if others start chatting in the thread. If you ever need to add someone or remove someone from the group your only option is to start a brand new MMS thread, and you can’t stop people from chatting on the old threads.

item.title: Scheduling automated storage health checks
item.description: and emailing yourself the results Most modern storage mediums (hard drives and solid state drives) have something call S.M.A.R.T. monitoring (Self-Monitoring, Analysis and Reporting Technology). Basically disks have built in monitoring systems that detect errors and can frequently predict drive failure before any data loss has occurred. This built in monitoring can be much more useful if you leverage it at the operating system level. I’m going to show you how you can schedule drive tests and configure them to send you updates to your personal email.

item.title: Scheduling automated ZFS scrubs
item.description: and emailing yourself the results One of the big benefits to using ZFS is its ability to repair silent data corruption. There are two ways it can do this. When it reads data from disk, it will check the data against its stored checksum. If the data doesn’t pass this check, it will pull the same data from the other disk in a mirror configuration or from the rest of the disk array.

item.description: Your text editor could look like this. Sublime Text 3 is without a doubt my favorite text editor. item.title: Why my blog is on Medium
item.description: Instead of WordPress, Ghost, or Github Pages The Ghost blogging platform got its initial start on kickstarter. When I first read about it, it sounded perfect! item.title: Writing code remotely with SSHFS
item.description: Where I work, each developer has their own virtual machine that is only available inside our corporate network. Each developer has all their code on their laptops, and it is shared with their VM using NFS. This works great while inside the office, but sometimes we need to work from home. The way our VPN is currently configured, our laptops do not keep the same internal IP address as they have when they are physically on the office network.
